Topic.Title: M. Dell Can Pay Twice His Current Offer and Still Make Lots of Money on Buy Out

Message.Msg: here is another option if Dell doesn't raise the offer price for buyer. institution shareholders will vote no and elect new independent BOD members via proxy fight. New BOD can decide to tender offer Mike Dell's 15% at $13.65. Then select a new CEO that is competent and professional to run the company to maximize shareholders value. This way, shareholders will bear the risk and Dell can cash out at $13.65 and get lost.

Message.Title: If the deal is rejected by shareholders, $13.65 will be the bottom, not the top of dell...
Message.Msg: If most shareholders think $13.65 is too low, we know that at least 50% of the shareholders + Michael Dell will not sell at $13.65 or below. It's hard to get lower than $13.65 (it can with short-seller, but will not be down that much). This is very different than the yahoo takeover from msft. That deal was rejected by the CEO while every shareholder wants to sell, Dell is the exact opposite.

Topic.Title: What do you think will happen? from your experience...

Message.Msg: I plan to vote no until a much better offer surfaces and I think the Southwestern letter will rally the support of many shareholders who think this is a pretty bad deal even if it's supposedly 25% above the price when rumors started. Michael Dell is not looking out for investors, as if he was he'd give an option to shareholders who want to stay in after the LBO to retain their shares. He could have also simply continued executing his plan as a public company that he boasted would boost revenues by 2015 and not try to gain more control of a private company. Nobody would boost their stake of a company that is in decline - he definitely sees a turning point where the company will make more money than previously and start gaining traction in the corporate sector that IBM dominates. The stock has a floor now of 13.65 - and it will go up in anticipation of a better deal.

Message.Title: Dell, Is That Really A Fair Offer?
Message.Msg: Congratulations are in order for Mr. Dell and his partners on the announcement to pay $13.65 per share to take Dell (DELL) private. However, it was surprising that Dell's board agreed to the price. Here is why. When Dell purchased Perot Systems this is the discussion on premium paid: On September 18, 2009, the last full day of trading before the public announcement of the terms of the Offer and the Merger, the closing price of the Shares on the NYSE was $17.91 per Share. On October 1, 2009, the last full day of trading before the commencement of the Offer, the closing price of the Shares on the NYSE was $29.72 per Share. The Offer Price represents a premium of approximately 67.5% over the closing price of the Shares on the NYSE on September 18, 2009, the last full day of trading before the public announcement of the Offer and the Merger, a premium of approximately 76.5% over the average closing price of the Shares one month prior to such announcement and a premium of approximately 115.4% over the average closing price of the Shares for the one year period ended September 18, 2009. With the Quest Software purchase the discussion was: The current and historical market price of the Company common stock, including the fact that the Per Share Merger Consideration represents a premium of approximately 44% over the closing price of the Company common stock on March 8, 2012, the day before the Company announced its entry into the Insight Merger Agreement, and 37% and 42% premiums over the 1-month and 2-month average trading price prior to such announcement, respectively; The Compellent purchase. The fact that $27.75 per share represents a premium of 46% to the estimated unaffected stock price of $19 per share. See "The Merger - Opinions of Compellent's Advisors" for a description of the estimation of an illustrative "unaffected" share price of Compellent common stock. The fact that $27.75 per share represents a premium of 26% to the three month average closing trading prices of share of Compellent common stock; the fact that $27.75 per share represents a premium of 133.9% to Compellent's stock price of $11.86 per share on the day prior to the date of announcement of Dell's initial offer to acquire 3PAR and a premium of 84.9% to Compellent's stock price of $15.01 per share on the day prior to September 1, 2010, the first day of the speculative rumors about Compellent's possible acquisition; This is in the Dell proposal to go private: Under the terms of the agreement, Dell stockholders will receive $13.65 in cash for each share of Dell common stock they hold, in a transaction valued at approximately $24.4 billion. The price represents a premium of 25 percent over Dell's closing share price of $10.88 on Jan. 11, 2013, the last trading day before rumors of a possible going-private transaction were first published; a premium of approximately 35 percent over Dell's enterprise value as of Jan. 11, 2013; and a premium of approximately 37 percent over the average closing share price during the previous 90 calendar days ending Jan. 11, 2013. The buyers will acquire for cash all of the outstanding shares of Dell not held by Mr. Dell and certain other members of management. On February 4th, 2013 the day before the merger announcement Dell closed at $13.27. If Dell offered the 84.9% premium that Compellent enjoyed before rumors, then the price would have been roughly $20.00 If Dell offered the 44% premium Quest Software enjoyed the day before the merger announcement, then the price would have been roughly $19.00. If Dell offered the 67.5% premium that Perot Systems enjoyed, then the price would have been roughly $22.00. If Dell offered a 25% premium on the more recently purchased, treasury stock then the price would have been roughly $19.00. If Dell offered the average price of the treasury stock on the balance sheet, then the price would have been $26.67. So why is Dell only offering $13.65? It would appear that a price in the range of $19.00 to $26.67 might be more appropriate. At $13.65, the board is agreeing to sell the entire firm for roughly $25 billion. Is this an admission that the $32 billion of owners' money given to departing owners was a mistake? Owners provided departing owners with roughly $7 billion more than has been agreed to sell the entire firm. This is a huge difference. Had the $32 billion been returned to owners via dividends, then the total enjoyed by owners would have been $57 billion.

Message.Title: Vote on Dell merger - I am extremely mad
Message.Msg: I have a small investment in Dell. Roughly 9000 shares. I purchased most of these believing in Michael Dell at roughly 30 to 35 dollars a share. I have purchased numerous Dell computers in past 18 years. This deal is so unfair. I am voting against it. If this deal goes through, Michael Dell is trying to steal the company and rob me who has believed in him and his company for so many years. Anyone associated with this deal who is conduit to stealing my family money I will make sure I will never deal with them again. i will never buy a dell computer again. If it comes to vote , i will vote every board member who voted for this deal out of the board if I can. I am talking to all my friends and relatives in detail about this bad deal who is taking money off the table and enriching Dell, Microsoft, and few people in Silver Lake and their bankers. They are all crooks. I think I will start buying only apple products/ computers. I will steer clear anything that has Microsoft's name on it. How could our board of directors vote on such a lop sided deal in favor of dell? Part of the whole deal is financed by our companies cash / bonds that are off shore. Out of $24 billion dollars needed, Silver Lake Michael Dell, Microsoft and bankers have found a way to use $11 to $12 billion to pay for it. If this group backs out or higher bid comes in, they get penalty hundreds of millions of dollars? Where is sense of fairness? I am considering putting in a complaint with the government on multiple levels.

Topic.Title: Vote on Dell merger - I am extremely mad

Message.Msg: why do you change your tune so often bashford???.... last night you said the vote WILL pass: "For conversation let's say DELL is a pie of 100 shares. Mike has 16 shares, and we will remove those from the pie, making the voting pie 84 shares.Southeastern has 8 shares, which they are threatening to vote against the merger. Add to that a few other large shareholders who comibned have 8 votes. So, worst case scenario 16 of 84 votes (from significant shareowners)will be NO. But let's add a bunch of passionate little amateurs like fluteman or CTG or mrphile who are sitting at home in t-shirt and jeans, sweating their 500 share positions here. But, because they watched some 15 year old Hollywood movie about Wall Street , they think they know how the game is played. For conversation let's add every little fools share count to the mix and call it 25 NO votes out of 84. Understand, the overwehleming majority of shareowners never cast a vote, And, plenty are very pleased to get $13.65 for their shares, becase that's a lot better price than $10, where DELL traded much of last year. Get the picture now? hope this helps." now you're saying the vote WILL NOT pass: "Considering that nost stockholders never actually vote , this nearly ensures Mike Dell's buyout offer will not be accepted." seriously, make up your mind. you can't have it both ways!

Topic.Title: Vote on Dell merger - I am extremely mad

Message.Msg: It was only two days ago I learned stockholders not voting their shares will be registered as NO votes. That is an unusual condition, which I expect Dell's LBO team installed to protect itself against litigation. Considering the reluctance stocholders have to ever cast a vote, it is most likely the LBO team's offer will not receive enough votes. I estimate a 95% chance the LBO team offer doesn't receive enough votes and Dell will remain a public company.

Topic.Title: What do you think will happen? from your experience...

Message.Msg: Due to the significant gap between the current LBO price and Southwestern Group's cost basis, there is no way the LBO group can raise the price enough to satisfy Southwestern Group. One scenario I think can happen is to let Southwestern Group to swap its stock holding to get a stake in the private Dell, while sweeten the deal a little to mollify the others smaller institutional and individual stock holders.

Topic.Title: What do you think will happen? from your experience...

Message.Msg: Bashford - It is perplexing to me that you agree that $13.65/sh. fairly values Dell. Having followed the statements of Mason Hawkins for many years, and recognizing that he has deep experience in valuing firms, I can not understand why shareholders should not demand a $5 - $6 special dividend, a Dutch auction or some other mechanism by which @ $20/sh could be realized. How the BOD approved this is baffling, and, ostensibly, a conflict of interest.
